awd_titl_txt: EXP: Readily Available Learning Experiences: Turning the Entire Web into Progressive Examples to Bridge Conceptual Knowledge Gaps for Novice Web Developers
awd_abstract_narration:
Computing is changing our world, and there is an urgent need to train large numbers of professional developers to meet the demands of our nation's economy. While it is relatively easy to learn basic computing concepts, acquiring the conceptual knowledge and problem-solving skills of professional developers is challenging. Learners currently lack the materials needed to support their progression from writing functional code to writing production-quality software. To address this gap, this project will develop new technologies that transform the entire web of professional examples into opportunities for authentic learning. Professional web applications provide rich details missing from training examples, and offer opportunities for learners to think in the modes of the discipline. By making professional websites available as a learning resource, this project aims to improve learners' conceptual understanding and better prepare them for programming challenges in professional work.
 
Novice developers lack the expert knowledge and self-directed skills required to (1) build conceptual models of professional examples; (2) implement professional features; and (3) apply professional concepts to solve diverse problems. This project aims to help learners overcome these challenges with Readily Available Learning Experiences (RALE), a theoretical model and platform that supports self-directed learning by: (1) scaffolding sensemaking to help learners build conceptual models of professional website features; (2) scaffolding process management to help learners implement concepts from professional examples; and (3) scaffolding reflection and articulation to support learning to apply concepts across diverse problems. To realize RALE in software, the researchers will develop computational techniques for implementing mixed-initiative scaffolds that leverage learner-created artifacts in conjunction with automated methods to support learning. This project will study the effectiveness of the RALE model using a design-based research process and generate empirically-validated principles to advance our understanding of authentic learning environments that provide a window into professional work.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to design cyberlearning technologies that scaffold learning from professional examples to bridge conceptual knowledge gaps for novice web developers. While it is relatively easy to learn basic computing concepts from tutorial examples, acquiring the conceptual knowledge and problem-solving skills of professional developers is challenging. Learners currently lack the materials needed to support their progression from writing functional code to writing production-quality software. We proposed a new cyberlearning genre, Readily Available Learning Experiences (RALE), that transforms professional web applications into an authentic resource for learning programming concepts, practicing concept implementations, and applying concepts across problems. But while professional examples provide an invaluable resource for learning, they pose an enormous cognitive burden for novice developers who lack the expert models needed for making sense of them. To overcome this challenge, we created a set of learner-centric tools that embeds computational techniques and sensemaking scaffolds informed by the learning sciences that together support learners more effectively investigating examples, managing their learning process, assessing what they have learned, and driving further investigation. This work vastly increases the number of scaffolded professional examples that can be used as a learning resource to supports learners improving the breadth, depth, and quality of their conceptual understanding.

 

Specifically, the project led to four new learner-centric tools for examining professional code examples: 

(1) Isopleth, a web-based platform for making sense of complex code constructs and hidden asynchronous relationships in professional web applications. Isopleth embeds sensemaking scaffolds informed by the learning sciences to help learners build conceptual models of how components coordinate to produce functionality in complex professional code. 

(2) Ply, a CSS inspection tool that helps novices use their visual intuition to make sense of professional webpages. We introduce a new visual relevance testing technique to identify properties that have visual effects on the page, which Ply uses to hide visually irrelevant code and surface unintuitive relationships between code properties.

(3) Knowledge Maps (KM), a tool that allows novice learners to build transferable and conceptual knowledge of CSS techniques across professional websites. KM helps learners  explore and compare various website examples by linking code to visual outcomes, and build  knowledge maps that group visual attributes of these websites with the CSS techniques used to produce them. 

(4) Scaffolded Exercises (SE), a tool that helps novice to intermediate web developers understand how value transformations produce complex interactive behaviors. SE introduces reverse call stack sequencing as a novel process management framework that incrementally exposes information about value transformations that lead to visual updates on the page that draws on learner's visual intuitions.

 

Our evaluation work demonstrated the effectiveness of the RALE approach. Results from four studies of Isopleth and Ply show that using these tools helped novice developers build significantly more accurate conceptual models of how professional features are implemented, and helped to surface expert design patterns across a diverse range of complex, professional websites. Specifically, Isopleth helped junior developers improve the accuracy of their conceptual models of how features are implemented by 31% on average, and  Ply helped novice developers replicate complex web features 50% faster than those using Chrome Developer Tools. Both tools also allowed novices to recognize and explain unfamiliar concepts. Moreover, an early study of KM led to a 48% increase in accuracy in mapping visual outcomes to CSS techniques, as compared to a 15% increase for non-KM users.

 

These findings suggest that we can create more learner-centric tools for learning from professional code examples to help novice and intermediate developers gain conceptual knowledge. More broadly, our work on RALE informs the design and study of authentic learning environments that provide a window into professional work by allowing learners to visualize abstractions, practice concepts, and tinker with complex artifacts across vast numbers of real-world examples. 

 

To advance the broader impacts of the proposed work, we (1) worked with the Firefox team to deploy Ply as a core feature in Firefox, a browser used by over 100 million users; (2) open-sourced our tools, including instrumentation code that makes it easier for others to build tools that support learning from professional web examples; and (3) trained 2 PhD student and 12 undergraduate students (including eight female students) through the Design, Technology, and Research program, following a novel research training approach that we have pioneered. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2022
Modified by: Haoqi Zhang

Images (1 of )
  • Isopleth is a sensemaking platform that supports learners studying the call graphs of complex interactive websites. It provides automated and interactive supports for exposing functional and asynchronous relationships, surfacing slices of code, and manipulating the provided code representation.
    Haoqi Zhang, Nell O'Rourke, and Josh Hibschman
    Copyrighted
    Haoqi Zhang
    Isopleth
  • Ply is a CSS inspection tool that helps novices use their visual intuition to make sense of professional webpages. Ply�s inspection interface minimizes visually irrelevant information, and surfaces unintuitive relationships between properties by revealing dependencies between CSS properties.
    Haoqi Zhang, Nell O'Rourke, and Sarah Lim
    Copyrighted
    Haoqi Zhang
    Ply
  • Knowledge Maps is a tool encourages novice web developers to construct conceptual models by comparing and contrasting professional web features across websites and their implementations.
    Haoqi Zhang, Nell O'Rourke, Roxy Wilcox, and Fardeem Munir
    Copyrighted
    Haoqi Zhang
    Knowledge Maps
  • Scaffolded Exercises (SE) is a tool that helps novice to intermediate web developers understand how variable transform to produce visual outputs in interactive web apps. SE helps learners trace interconnections across variables in reverse call stack order to understand how the code works.
    Haoqi Zhang, Nell O'Rourke, Jonathan Liu
    Copyrighted
    Haoqi Zhang
    Scaffolded Exercises

The goal of this project was to design cyberlearning technologies that scaffold learning from professional examples to bridge conceptual knowledge gaps for novice web developers. While it is relatively easy to learn basic computing concepts from tutorial examples, acquiring the conceptual knowledge and problem-solving skills of professional developers is challenging.
